abstract.p: Frank Litsky matchups of weekend's key college football games; photo (M)

block.p: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

NO. 4 NEBRASKA 7-0 NO. 1at OKLAHOMA 6-0 The biggest game of the season so far. The first Bowl Championship Series standing of the season ranks Nebraska first and Oklahoma second. Both have punishing offenses and tight defenses. In its last two games, Oklahoma beat Texas, scoring 63 points, and Kansas State, scoring 41. But in their last three meetings, Nebraska has outscored the Sooners, 179-28.TV: CH7, Noon
TODAY'S KEY GAMES

NO. 4 NEBRASKA 7-0 NO. 1at OKLAHOMA 6-0 The biggest game of the season so far. The first Bowl Championship Series standing of the season ranks Nebraska first and Oklahoma second. Both have punishing offenses and tight defenses. In its last two games, Oklahoma beat Texas, scoring 63 points, and Kansas State, scoring 41. But in their last three meetings, Nebraska has outscored the Sooners, 179-28.TV: CH7, Noon

NO. 6FLORIDA 6-1 NO. 8vs. GEORGIA at Jacksonville, Fla. 6-1 Both must win to stay in the race in the Southeastern Conference's East Division. Georgia's strong defense allowed 528 passing yards to Kentucky last week and Florida has the nation's top-ranked passer in Rex Grossman. Quincy Carter, the Georgia quarterback, returns from a shoulder injury.

NO. 10OHIO STATE 6-1 NO. 20at PURDUE 6-2 Purdue is favored because of quarterback Drew Brees and the home-field advantage. If it wins, it should also beat Michigan State and Indiana in its last two games and get to the Rose Bowl.TV: CH7, 3:30 P.M.
OTHER GAMES
EAST Rutgers (3-4) at Boston College (4-3) Boston College should win big despite a defense that gave up 584 yards to Pitt. TV: CH9, Noon
No. 19 Toledo (6-1) at Navy (0-7) Navy is combining bad offense with bad defense.
Columbia (3-3) at Yale (5-1) Yale, Harvard, Penn, Princeton and Cornell are tied for the Ivy League lead.
Princeton (2-4) at Cornell (2-4) Last week, Cornell passed for 446 yards, ran for a mere 4 and lost to Brown, 56-40.
SOUTH Pittsburgh (5-1) at No. 2 Virginia Tech (7-0) After a scare from Syracuse, Virginia Tech faces a solid Big East foe today and another (Miami) next Saturday. TV: CH2, 3:30 P.M.

No. 5 Florida State (7-1) at No. 16 N.C. State (5-1) After Florida State smothered Virginia with 5 turnovers, 5 sacks and 199 yards total offense, Coach George Welsh of Virginia said, ''I don't remember anybody ever stopping us cold like that -- ever.'' TV: ESPN, 7 P.M.
No. 25 Georgia Tech (5-2) at No. 11 Clemson (8-0) Clemson cannot look ahead to Florida State next week.
Tennessee (3-3) at No. 15 So. Carolina (7-1) A tough test for South Carolina's big running game.
MIDWEST Air Force (5-2) at No. 12 Notre Dame (5-2)
Notre Dame has won three straight, and as running back Tony Fisher said, ''We're playing with confidence.'' TV: CH4, 2:30 P.M.
Northwestern (5-2) at Minnesota (5-3) Minnesota gets big yardage and gives it up, too. TV: ESPN2, Noon
Penn State (3-5) vs. Indiana (3-4) at Indianapolis Penn State must stop Antwaan Randel El, who passed for 263 yards and ran for 210 in an upset of Minnesota. TV: ESPN2, 7 P.M.
SOUTHWEST No. 13 Kansas State (7-1) at No. 23 Texas A&M (5-2) In its last two games, Kansas State lost to Oklahoma and just beat Texas Tech.
No. 22 Southern Miss. (5-1) at Houston (3-4) Southern Mississippi has won five straight, all one-sided.
Rice (2-5) at Texas Christian (6-0) Should be easy for Texas Christian's top-ranked defense (246.1 yards a game).
FAR WEST No. 9 Oregon (6-1) at Arizona State (5-2) Oregon leads the Pacific-10, a game ahead of Oregon State, Washington and Arizona.
No. 7 Washington (6-1) at Stanford (3-4) Both needed fourth-quarter heroics to survive last week.

Washington State (3-4) at No. 14 Oregon State (6-1) Although Oregon State has become a national power, wide receiver Chad Johnson laments, ''We have not gotten any respect at all.'' TV: FSNY, 10:30 P.M.
U.C.L.A. (4-3) at No. 24 Arizona (5-2) U.C.L.A. can run, but probably not against this defense.
No. 18 Colorado State (6-1) at San Diego State (2-5) Colorado State needed two long touchdown passes in the fourth quarter to beat Utah.
MISMATCHES
Louisiana Tech (2-6) at No. 3 Miami (5-1) Louisiana Tech, which passed for 433 yards in losing to Auburn, won't get that yardage again.
Middle Tennessee (3-4) at No. 17
Mississippi State (4-2) Mississippi State's great run defense, which suffered against Louisiana State, should right itself.
Baylor (2-5) at Texas (5-2) In its last three games, Baylor has lost to Texas Tech, Texas A&M and Nebraska by a combined score of 111-0
Rankings by The New York Times computer. All times are Eastern.
COLLEGE FOOTBALL
